Welcome to Behind the ticker.
Today we have on Mike Venuto.

Everything ETFs.

So please enjoy this episode with Mr. Mike Venuto.
Hey Mike, welcome back to the show.
Yeah, good to be back.
So why don't you just take a couple minutes refresh everybody who you are and tell everybody a little bit about title in your background.
Sure.
So my name is Mike Venuto.
I'm the co-founder and CEO of Title Financial Group.
Primarily we help people launch and grow an operating ETFs.
We've done it now for, well, right now I think there's 162 funds that we're servicing on our platform.
As the CIO, I also get involved with a lot of structuring as well as actively managing a few funds for our clients.
The last time I was on your show, we talked a lot about block.
That's one of my passions.
Recently, it took over managing Nancy and crews, which has been a lot of fun.
So, you know, basically we are a platform that can help you launch, grow an operating ETFs.
And we do everything from, you know, kind of that boring compliance work to fund active management as well as creative marketing, all that fun stuff.
Well, while you mentioned it, how is block going and just like maybe a little bit of an update there and it would be neat to hear.
I think the listeners would enjoy hearing like, how do you go about finding and placing trades for Nancy and what, what's the other one, crews?
Yeah. Okay. So, both block and Nancy and crews, I manage with Dan Weiss cough and the rest of the investment committee.
We actually have specific meetings for each fund and then we have a 15 person investment committee that meets every Monday and covers not just the active stuff, but also the passive stuff.
You know, we also actively manage why max, which is the fund of funds for the yield max family.
And a lot of it's tax optimization, all that fun stuff. So, we'll hit block first and we'll get a little bit into Nancy and crews.
With block, we're extremely active. I mean, we've, we've owned IPOs, we've owned convertible debt, we've owned Bitcoin through Canadian ETFs and through US ETFs.
We have Dan on the Bitcoin mining council, we speak to sailor all the time, Novigratz's crew, all the miners.
So, it's very much an understanding of the ecosystem, right? You could talk to all the blockchain companies you want. They're all going to tell you their story.
But really where you get into the weeds and get to know things in that ecosystem is by asking about the supply chain and who they're buying chips from and who they're storing with and all that.
So, block is having an extremely good year. Not a surprise considering the underlying commodity of Bitcoin has had a pretty good year as well.
So, you know, we're up north of 25% as of this recording, which is, I would say, a pretty good year.
Nancy and crews are very different. We're not meeting with management. We're not making a call on the business. What we're doing is we have a research agreement with unusual whales.
And the partner in that is a company called subversive who set up everything originally and then they brought us into actively manage it.
When they were managing it in the previous iteration, it was extremely, extremely diversified. One fund had Nancy had 700 stocks, plus and crews was like 400 plus.
When we took over data and I as managers, we decided to work with Oscar over at unusual whales, really partial through the data and really hone in on patterns that are true signals.
What I think, you know, if you just take the data and look at everything they own, well, some of these people hire, I don't know, parametrics to do direct indexing for them.
They don't really care about those three shares of STL. They don't really have any insight, but it gets thrown into the mix. So we've really tried to consolidate down into names where we see a pattern of multiple people buying or somebody on a specific committee that might have some information.
But for those who don't know, these two funds basically take the stock act, which requires that congressional members disclose what they've purchased.
The majority is congressional members are allowed to make investments in things where they would, for otherwise called insight information, right?
Like there's really no way to show it.
It's the other way to say it.

And then cruise does the exact same thing, but it's members of Congress that are in their Republican party.
This year, Nancy is outpacing crews, but they both have very nice diversified returns for the year.
I mean, we could probably do a whole episode on those two.

I mean that that'll be a floodgates thing if the share class then gets through I think it's probably two years off but you know who am I to say.
